title: Sophie Ellis-Bextor

'''Sophie Michelle Ellis-Bextor''' (born 10 April 1979)<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.hellomagazine.com/profiles/sophie-ellis-bextor/ |title=Sophie Ellis-Bextor – Biography |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=April 2008 |website=[[Hello! (magazine)|Hello!]] |access-date=29 July 2020|archive-url=https://archive.today/20200729064840/https://www.hellomagazine.com/profiles/sophie-ellis-bextor/ |archive-date=29 July 2020}}</ref> is an English singer and songwriter. She first came to prominence in the late 1990s, as the lead singer of the [[indie rock]] band [[Theaudience (band)|Theaudience]]. After the group disbanded, Ellis-Bextor went solo, achieving success in the early 2000s. Her music is a mixture of mainstream [[Pop music|pop]], [[disco]], [[nu-disco]], and 1980s [[Electronic music|electronic]] influences.

Ellis-Bextor's debut solo album, ''[[Read My Lips (Sophie Ellis-Bextor album)|Read My Lips]]'', was released in 2001. It peaked at number two on the [[UK Albums Chart]]<ref name="ukcharts2">{{cite web|url=https://www.officialcharts.com/artist/11003/sophie-ellis-bextor/|title=Sophie Ellis-Bextor {{!}} Full Official Chart History|publisher=[[Official Charts Company]]|access-date=12 August 2022}}</ref> and was certified double platinum by the [[British Phonographic Industry]];<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bpi.co.uk/platinum/platinumright.asp?rq=search_plat&r_id=30243|title=Certified Awards|publisher=[[British Phonographic Industry]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930232045/http://www.bpi.co.uk/platinum/platinumright.asp?rq=search_plat&r_id=30243|date=21 June 2002|archive-date=30 September 2007|access-date=12 August 2022|url-status=dead}}</ref> it sold 1.5 million copies worldwide.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nme.com/news/ellis-sophie-bextor/15064|title=Bex is back!|website=[[NME]]|date=11 September 2003|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120406195219/http://www.nme.com/news/ellis-sophie-bextor/15064|archive-date=6 April 2012|access-date=12 August 2022|url-status=dead}}</ref> Three of its four singles—the [[Cher]] cover "[[Take Me Home (Cher song)#Sophie Ellis-Bextor version|Take Me Home]]", "[[Murder on the Dancefloor]]" and the double A-side [[Get Over You / Move This Mountain|"Get Over You" / "Move This Mountain"]]—reached the top three in the UK.<ref name="ukcharts2"/> In 2003, ''Read My Lips'' won the Edison Award for Best Dance Album.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.edisons.nl/pop/edities/2003/|title=2003 - Edison Pop|website=Edisons|access-date=12 August 2022|language=nl-NL}}</ref> Its follow-up ''[[Shoot from the Hip]]'' (2003) reached number 19 in the UK and spawned two top ten singles, "[[Mixed Up World]]" and "[[I Won't Change You]]".<ref name="ukcharts2"/>

Ellis-Bextor's third studio album, ''[[Trip the Light Fantastic (Sophie Ellis-Bextor album)|Trip the Light Fantastic]]'' (2007), peaked at number seven in the UK and its lead single "[[Catch You]]" reached the top ten.<ref name="ukcharts2"/> Her fourth studio album, ''[[Make a Scene]]'' (2011), and its third single "[[Bittersweet (Sophie Ellis-Bextor song)|Bittersweet]]" achieved top 40 positions in the UK.<ref name="ukcharts2"/> Her fifth studio album, ''[[Wanderlust (Sophie Ellis-Bextor album)|Wanderlust]]'' (2014), peaked at number four, becoming her highest-charting album since ''Read My Lips''.<ref name="ukcharts2"/> She released her [[Latin music|Latin]]-inspired sixth studio album ''[[Familia (Sophie Ellis-Bextor album)|Familia]]'' in 2016 to critical acclaim.

==Early life==
[[File:Sophie Ellis-Bextor's stamp collection Spring Stampex 2018 05.jpg|thumb|upright=0.8|Ellis-Bextor's childhood stamp collection at [[Stampex|Spring Stampex 2018]]]]
Ellis-Bextor was born in [[London]] to [[Janet Ellis]], who was a presenter on [[BBC]]'s [[children's television]] programmes ''[[Blue Peter]]'' and ''[[Jigsaw (UK TV series)|Jigsaw]]'', and [[Robin Bextor]], a film producer and director: they separated when she was four.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2011/jul/16/sophie-ellis-bextor-family-values|title=Sophie Ellis-Bextor. The singer talks about her family|date=16 July 2011|work=[[The Guardian]]|access-date=30 December 2011|first=Nick|last=Duerden}}</ref> As a child, Ellis-Bextor occasionally appeared on ''Blue Peter'' alongside her mother, who presented the programme.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/cbbc/findoutmore/bp-presenters-then-and-now|title=Blue Peter – Blue Peter Presenters: Then and Now|language=en|access-date=15 October 2018}}</ref>

She attended [[St. Stephen's School, Twickenham|St. Stephen's School]] and later the [[Independent school|independent]] [[Godolphin and Latymer School]] in [[Hammersmith]]. Among her earliest public performances were with the [[W11 Opera]] children's opera from the age of thirteen, and she is now a patron of the organisation.<ref name="W11 Opera Website">{{cite web|url=http://w11opera.org/pages/patrons.html |title=W11 Opera, Patrons |publisher=W11opera.org |access-date=17 August 2010 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091209001526/http://www.w11opera.org/pages/patrons.html |archive-date=9 December 2009}}</ref>

Ellis-Bextor has said, "I didn't see myself as a good-looking girl and that was good, because I didn't rely on it. (…) I've now found lots of like-minded weirdos, so it's OK."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/aug/27/question-time-sophie-ellis-bextor|title=Question time: Sophie Ellis-Bextor|first=Emine|last=Saner|date=26 August 2009|access-date=8 January 2019|work=The Guardian}}</ref>

==Career==
===1996–99: ''Theaudience''===
{{main|Theaudience (band)}}
Ellis-Bextor began her professional musical career in 1996, singing lead vocals in [[Independent music|indie]] band [[Theaudience (band)|Theaudience]].  The band released four singles, including the [[UK Top 40]] hits "[[I Know Enough (I Don't Get Enough)]]", and "[[A Pessimist Is Never Disappointed]]", and one self-titled album (''[[Theaudience (album)|theaudience]]'' (1999)). Videos for the band's singles were directed by her father, Robin Bextor.  While in Theaudience, readers of ''[[Melody Maker]]'' voted Ellis-Bextor number one in a poll of 'most sexy people in rock'.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sophie-online.net/en/info/theaudience.php |title=Theaudience |access-date=13 April 2021 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150224012354/http://sophie-online.net/en/info/theaudience.php |archive-date=24 February 2015}}</ref><ref name="The Great Rock Discography">{{cite book
| first= Martin C.
| last= Strong
| year= 2000
| title= The Great Rock Discography
| edition= 5th
| publisher= Mojo Books
| location= Edinburgh
| page= 980
| isbn= 1-84195-017-3}}</ref>

The band split in 1999 after demos for a planned second album were rejected by their label [[Mercury Records]], who then dropped the band.<ref name="The Great Rock Discography" />  Ellis-Bextor recorded a duet with [[Manic Street Preachers]] — "Black Holes for the Young" — as a B-side for their 1998 single "[[The Everlasting (song)|The Everlasting]]",<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nme.com/music-interviews/rock-n-roll-kill-braincells-sophie-ellis-bextor-2403298|title=Does Rock 'N' Roll Kill Braincells?! – Sophie Ellis-Bextor | NME|website=[[NME]]|date=19 November 2018|access-date=7 April 2020}}</ref> and in 1999, made an appearance on the [[Departure Lounge (band)|Departure Lounge]] album ''[[Out of Here (Departure Lounge album)|Out of Here]]''.

===2000–2006: ''Read My Lips'' and  ''Shoot from the Hip'' ===
After Theaudience split, Ellis-Bextor collaborated with Italian DJ [[Spiller]], in 2000, adding vocals to his track "[[Groovejet (If This Ain't Love)]]". It entered the UK charts at number one, just beating former [[Spice Girls|Spice Girl]] [[Victoria Beckham]] on her first solo track. "Groovejet" won several awards: No. 1, Pop Top 20; No. 1, ILR; No. 1, Radio 1; No. 8, top dance track of 2000 and single of the year in ''Melody Maker''. In the ''Metro Newspaper'', it received ninth place in the contest for the Greatest No. 1 of all time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.djcode.net/djspiller.html |title=Melody Maker 2000 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160106164210/http://www.djcode.net/djspiller.html |archive-date=6 January 2016 }}</ref> In 2000, it was a finalist in ''[[The Record of the Year]]''. In that same year, it won the awards for Best Single and Best Ibiza Tune at the Ericsson Muzik Awards.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/979958.stm |title=Spiller and Jaxx take Muzik honours |publisher=BBC News |date=19 October 2000 |access-date=17 August 2010}}</ref>

In 2001, Ellis-Bextor released her début album, ''[[Read My Lips (Sophie Ellis-Bextor album)|Read My Lips]]''. It reached number two on the UK charts and spawned four top-twenty hit singles. Her rework of [[Cher]]'s "[[Take Me Home (Cher song)|Take Me Home]]" reached number two, as did "[[Murder on the Dancefloor]]", which became Ellis-Bextor's biggest single and was on charts for twenty-three weeks.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://top40-charts.com/song.php?sid=2700&sort=chartid&string=Sophie |title=Murder on the Dancefloor, World Charts |publisher=Top40-charts.com |access-date=17 August 2010}}</ref> "Murder on the Dancefloor" became Europe's most played song of 2002. In 2002, ''Read My Lips'' was re-released with two new songs (and a live version of "Groovejet") and Ellis-Bextor won the Recording Artist Award at that year's Showbusiness Awards. Her third single, "[[Get Over You / Move This Mountain]]", was released in June 2002 and reached number three. The fourth single, "[[Music Gets the Best of Me]]", rose to number fourteen in December. At the beginning of 2002, Ellis-Bextor was nominated for the "British Female Solo Artist" [[BRIT Awards|BRIT Award]], going on to be nominated for a further two consecutive years.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ukmix.org/articles/2004/brits.html |title=BRIT Awards 2004 |publisher=Ukmix.org |access-date=17 August 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029210145/http://www.ukmix.org/articles/2004/brits.html |archive-date=29 October 2013 |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Culture |url=https://www.theguardian.com/arts/news/story/0,,874173,00.html |title=The Brits 2003, The Nominees |work=The Guardian |date=13 January 2003 |access-date=17 August 2010 | location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.contactmusic.com/new/home.nsf/webpages/brit2002 |title=Brits Awards: The Nominees |publisher=Contactmusic.com |date=15 November 2007 |access-date=17 August 2010}}</ref>

Her second album, ''[[Shoot from the Hip]]'', was released in October 2003 and yielded two further top-ten singles, "[[Mixed Up World]]" and "[[I Won't Change You]]".<ref name="ukcharts2" /> The album reached number 19 on the UK charts and was certified silver by the [[British Phonographic Industry|BPI]] for shipments of 60,000.<ref name="ukcharts2" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bpi.co.uk/certified-awards.aspx |website=British Phonographic Industry |title=Certified Awards |access-date=7 April 2014 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150315204844/http://www.bpi.co.uk/certified-awards.aspx |archive-date=15 March 2015}}</ref> Ellis-Bextor described the album as "more emotionally direct" and "a little more left-of-centre at times" than ''Read My Lips''—"It has more of a live feel [...] It's still a pop album—with elements of disco, indie and rock."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/3207811.stm|title=Sophie Ellis-Bextor turns up the heat|date=26 October 2003|publisher=BBC}}</ref> She opted to step back from promotion of the album after becoming pregnant.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.perthnow.com.au/news/wa/tripping-the-light-fantastic-ng-0def4d0a405beba1581190667d9da1ec|title=Tripping the light fantastic|date=28 July 2007|website=PerthNow}}</ref>

In 2005, Ellis-Bextor was featured on the Busface single "[[Circles (Just My Good Time)]]" under the alias Mademoiselle E.B.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/whats-on/music/busface-feat-mademoiselle-eb---1061819|title=Busface feat. Mademoiselle E.B. – Circles (Just My Good Time) (Justice Brothers)|author=Manchester Evening News|date=30 June 2005|website=[[Manchester Evening News]]}}</ref>

===2007–2011: ''Trip the Light Fantastic'' and  ''Make a Scene'' ===
[[File:Ellis-bextoratgay.jpg|upright=0.8|thumb|Ellis-Bextor performing at [[G-A-Y]] in 2007]]

''[[Trip the Light Fantastic (Sophie Ellis-Bextor album)|Trip the Light Fantastic]]'', Ellis-Bextor's third album, was released in May 2007 and reached number seven in the UK.<ref name="ukcharts2" /> The album produced three singles: "[[Catch You]]" (number 8 in the UK), "[[Me and My Imagination]]" (number 23), and "[[Today the Sun's on Us]]" (number 64).<ref name="officialcharts">{{Cite web|url=https://www.officialcharts.com/artist/11003/sophie-ellis-bextor/|title=Sophie Ellis-Bextor | full Official Chart History |publisher=Official Charts Company}}</ref> The song "If I Can't Dance" was announced as a single but later retracted.<ref name=sebnet/><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/a69173/video-sophie-ellis-bextor.html|title=Video: Sophie Ellis-Bextor speaks|work=[[Digital Spy]]|date=2 August 2007|access-date=8 February 2007}}</ref>

Ellis-Bextor supported [[George Michael]] on his UK tour leg in June 2007. Her own UK tour, the Trip the Light Fantastic Tour, was due to start in August 2007, but it was postponed after Ellis-Bextor was invited to be the "special guest" on [[Take That]]'s [[Beautiful World Tour]], which commenced in October 2007.<ref name=sebnet>{{cite web|url=http://www.sophieellisbextor.net/ |title=Sophie Ellis-Bextor's official website |publisher=Sophieellisbextor.net |date=11 August 2010 |access-date=17 August 2010}}</ref> Ellis-Bextor stated that her tour would be rescheduled for March 2008, with all tickets purchased being valid for the rescheduled concerts. The tour was never rescheduled, and Ellis-Bextor subsequently refused to discuss the issue in interviews.<ref>"Isn't she lovely", Noozhumurry, J, The London Paper, 18 September 2008</ref> In October 2008, Ellis-Bextor sang at the Keep the Promise Rally in Trafalgar Square to end Child Poverty.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sophie Ellis-Bextor rallies round to end child poverty – 29th of Sep, 2008 |url=http://www.endchildpoverty.org.uk/news/news/sophie-ellis-bextor-rallies-round-to-end-child-poverty/23/129 |website=End Child Poverty |access-date=30 October 2014 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141030203733/http://www.endchildpoverty.org.uk/news/news/sophie-ellis-bextor-rallies-round-to-end-child-poverty/23/129 |archive-date=30 October 2014}}</ref>

In June 2009, Ellis-Bextor was featured on the [[Freemasons (band)|Freemasons]] single "[[Heartbreak (Make Me a Dancer)]]", which reached number 13 in the UK.<ref name="officialcharts"/> In July, she performed alongside girl groups [[The Saturdays]] and [[Girls Can't Catch]] at the iTunes Festival, held at the Roundhouse in London.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nme.com/news/music/placebo-15-1308439|title=Placebo, Calvin Harris, Bloc Party, Mika for free London shows | NME|website=[[NME]]|date=16 June 2009}}</ref> A recording of her performance was released, ''[[Sophie Ellis-Bextor: iTunes Live in London]]'', which was the singer's first extended play. "[[Bittersweet (Sophie Ellis-Bextor song)|Bittersweet]]" (co-written by Freemasons and [[Hannah Robinson]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.femalefirst.co.uk/music/news/Sophie+Ellis+Bextor-10252.html |title=Sophie Ellis Bextor's 'Bittersweet' Single |date=7 January 2010 |website=Female First |access-date=13 April 2021}}</ref>), the first single from Ellis-Bextor's fourth album, was released in May 2010 and reached 25 on the UK Singles Chart. Ellis-Bextor's collaboration with DJ [[Armin van Buuren]], "[[Not Giving Up on Love]]", was released as a single in August 2010 in Europe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arminvanbuuren.com/news/2010/08/not-giving-up-on-love-%e2%80%93-pre-order-and-studio-session-now-online/|title=Not Giving Up On Love' – Pre-order + studio session! – Armin van Buuren|work=Web site of DJ/Producer Armin van Buuren.|access-date=22 May 2016|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160405175902/http://www.arminvanbuuren.com/news/2010/08/not-giving-up-on-love-%e2%80%93-pre-order-and-studio-session-now-online/|archive-date=5 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/celebs/news/2009/12/09/bex-in-the-groove-115875-21883623/ |title=Sophie Ellis-Bextor to play with husband's band The Feeling at new Swiss festival as she teams up with DJ Armin van Buuren for new single |date=9 December 2009 |work=Daily Mirror |access-date=17 August 2010}}</ref>  Also in 2010, she was featured on the [[Junior Caldera]] single "[[Can't Fight This Feeling]]".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.discogs.com/Junior-Caldera-Feat-Sophie-Ellis-Bextor-Cant-Fight-This-Feeling/master/241138|title=Junior Caldera Feat. Sophie Ellis-Bextor – Can't Fight This Feeling|publisher=Discogs}}</ref>

The singer's fourth album, ''[[Make a Scene]]'', was released in June 2011 following a year-long delay, during which she left her label [[Universal Music Group]] to establish her own label, EBGBs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sophieellisbextor.net/news?id=329 |title=Sophie's new album and single out on 6 June! |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130131224228/http://sophieellisbextor.net/news?id=329 |archive-date=31 January 2013}}</ref>
<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/entertainment/music/news/why-did-sophie-find-it-hard-to-make-a-scene-28630172.html|title=Why did Sophie find it hard to make a scene?|newspaper=Belfast Telegraph}}</ref> Ellis-Bextor said that her decision to leave Universal was spurred on by the departure of the head of [[Fascination Records]], the sub-label to which she was signed, following the release of "Bittersweet".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/music/a324829/sophie-ellis-bextor-interview-im-a-sucker-for-sad-pop/|title=Sophie Ellis-Bextor interview: "I'm a sucker for sad pop"|first=Robert|last=Copsey|date=14 June 2011|website=Digital Spy}}</ref> Ellis-Bextor described ''Make a Scene'' as "very much [a dance album]—more so than any of my other albums."<ref name=":0" /> Ellis-Bextor said she was planning an "album that's really different [...] but I think this album [''Make a Scene''] is a good way to bow out of the dance sound for now. I think it's finishing on a high."<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/interviews/a214312/sophie-ellis-bextor.html |title=Music – Interview – Sophie Ellis-Bextor |work=Digital Spy |date=15 April 2010 |access-date=17 August 2010}}</ref> She supported [[Pet Shop Boys]] on the UK leg of their [[Pandemonium Tour]] in July 2010.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.petshopboys.co.uk/news/2010-06-23/sophie-is-a-special-guest|title = Sophie is a special guest}}</ref>  She worked with [[Calvin Harris]], [[Richard X]], [[Dimitri Tikovoi]], Hannah Robinson, [[Metronomy]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Jehan |first=Faisal |url=http://www.ohhcrapp.net/2008/09/interview-metronomy_13.html |title=Interview 'Metronomy' |publisher=Ohh! Crapp... |date=13 September 2008 |access-date=17 August 2010 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100402185651/http://www.ohhcrapp.net/2008/09/interview-metronomy_13.html |archive-date=2 April 2010 }}</ref> and [[Liam Howe]] from the [[Sneaker Pimps]]. "[[Off & On]]" preceded the release of the album in continental Europe and Russia, where the album was released by Universal Music Russia;<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.universalmusic.ru/ru/artists/201/news/1388/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140111175218/http://www.universalmusic.ru/ru/artists/201/news/1388/|url-status=dead|archive-date=11 January 2014|title=Universal Music Russia|date=11 January 2014}}</ref> in the UK, the single "[[Starlight (Sophie Ellis-Bextor song)|Starlight]]" was released ahead of the album in May 2011.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/music/single-reviews/a321627/sophie-ellis-bextor-starlight/|title=Sophie Ellis-Bextor: 'Starlight'|first=Robert|last=Copsey|date=26 May 2011|website=Digital Spy}}</ref>

Ellis-Bextor supported synth-pop band [[Erasure]] on their Total Pop! Forest tour of woodland locations in the UK in June 2011.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/entertainment/music/news/ellis-bextor-joins-erasure-for-tour-28591762.html|title=Ellis-Bextor joins Erasure for tour|newspaper=Belfast Telegraph}}</ref> She resumed touring internationally in 2011, playing venues such as [[Jakarta]]'s SoulNation festival, as well as returning to Australia by performing in Sydney and Melbourne.<ref>
[http://www.thejakartaglobe.com/lifeandtimes/soulnation-mixes-best-from-home-and-abroad/468064/ SoulNation mixes best from Home and Abroad] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111203020234/http://www.thejakartaglobe.com/lifeandtimes/soulnation-mixes-best-from-home-and-abroad/468064 |date=3 December 2011 }}  Jakarta Globe. 27 September 2011.
</ref> Ellis-Bextor collaborated with French DJ [[Bob Sinclar]] on a track titled "Fuck with You" (released in November 2011), which was included on his album ''Disco Crash'' and was a huge club hit in [[Continental Europe]].<ref>[http://idolator.com/6078572/sophie-ellis-bextor-fuck-with-you Sophie Ellis-Bextor Wants To "F*** With You" In New Bob Sinclar Track] Idolator. 15 November 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.hindustantimes.com/Entertainment/Music/It-s-the-time-to-disco-in-Delhi/Article1-778205.aspx It's Time To Disco in Delhi.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141021002908/http://www.hindustantimes.com/entertainment/music/it-s-the-time-to-disco-in-delhi/article1-778205.aspx |date=21 October 2014 }} HindustanTimes. 5 December 2011.</ref> Ellis-Bextor's collaboration with French DJ Mathieu Bouthier, "Beautiful", was released in July 2012 in France.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/fr/album/beautiful-radio-edit-feat./id541256558|title=Beautiful (Radio Edit) [feat. Sophie Ellis-Bextor] – Single|publisher=iTunes Store|access-date=22 May 2016}}</ref>

===2012–2014: ''Wanderlust'' and collaborations===
In May 2011, she revealed that she had begun work on her fifth album.<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/foodanddrink/healthyeating/8473612/My-Day-on-a-Plate-Sophie-Ellis-Bextor.html My Day on a Plate: Sophie Ellis-Bextor] ''The Daily Telegraph''. 1 May 2011</ref> Beginning in 2012, Ellis-Bextor worked with [[United Kingdom|British]] singer and producer [[Ed Harcourt]] on a "more [[concept album|concept driven record]]", and possibly having as few as eight tracks. Her performance at a [[London]] charity gala in November 2012 including a new song, "[[Young Blood (Sophie Ellis-Bextor song)|Young Blood]]";<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sophieellisbextor.net/news?id=414|title=Sophie Q&A, 6 December 2012|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130310061345/http://sophieellisbextor.net/news?id=414|archive-date=10 March 2013}}</ref> a demo of the song was released in March 2013 as a complimentary [[music download|digital download]] from her website, as a thank you gift to her fans.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sophieellisbextor.net/post/46356095810/download-sophies-new-song-young-blood-for-free|title=Download Sophie's new song, Young Blood, for free!|work=Sophie Ellis-Bextor|access-date=22 May 2016}}</ref> Also in 2013, she performed outdoors at Old Republic Square in [[Almaty]], [[Kazakhstan]].<ref>[http://sophieellisbextor.net/post/46241234977/heres-some-photos-of-sophie-performing-in-almaty "Some photos of Sophie performing in Almaty"] Retrieved 2 July 2015</ref> Ellis-Bextor confirmed completion of the album in May and revealed its title, ''[[Wanderlust (Sophie Ellis-Bextor album)|Wanderlust]]'', and cover art in October.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://mobile.twitter.com/SophieEB/status/334651427043561472?p=v |title=We've finished! |via=Twitter |access-date=13 April 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141222161843/https://mobile.twitter.com/SophieEB/status/334651427043561472?p=v |archive-date=22 December 2014}}{{Primary source inline|date=July 2022}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=10151968363712628 |title=Here's the album cover! |date=14 October 2013 |last=Ellis-Bextor |first=Sophie |via=Facebook |access-date=22 May 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160106164210/https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=10151968363712628 |archive-date=6 January 2016}}{{Primary source inline|date=July 2022}}</ref>

"Young Blood" was released as the lead single from ''Wanderlust'' in November 2013, peaking at number three on the [[UK Indie Chart]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio1/chart/indiesingles|title=BBC – Radio 1 – Charts – UK Top 30 Indie Singles Chart|work=Radio 1|access-date=22 May 2016}}</ref> and at number 34 on the [[UK Singles Chart]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.officialcharts.com/singles-chart/ |title=Official Singles Chart Top 100 |publisher=[[Official Charts Company]] |access-date=22 May 2016 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120501153930/http://www.officialcharts.com/singles-chart/ |archive-date=1 May 2012}}</ref> The album was released in January 2014 and peaked at number four on the [[UK Albums Chart]] and at number one on the [[UK Indie Chart|UK Independent Albums Chart]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.officialcharts.com/albums-chart/ |title=Official Albums Chart Top 100 |publisher=[[Official Charts Company]] |access-date=22 May 2016 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120428071146/http://www.officialcharts.com/albums-chart/ |archive-date=28 April 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.officialcharts.com/independent-albums-chart/|title=Official Independent Albums Chart Top 50|publisher=[[Official Charts Company]]|access-date=22 May 2016}}</ref> ''Wanderlust'' also debuted inside the Scottish Top 10 Albums Chart.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.officialcharts.com/scottish-albums-chart/ |title=Scottish Albums Chart |publisher=[[Official Charts Company]] |access-date=27 January 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921061126/http://www.officialcharts.com/scottish-albums-chart/ |archive-date=21 September 2013 |url-status=bot: unknown }}</ref> Ellis-Bextor performed a headline sold-out show to support ''Wanderlust''{{'}}s release in January 2014 at [[Bush Hall]], [[London]], and also performed at [[Union Chapel, Islington|Union Chapel]], London in April.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sophieellisbextor.net/post/64857687115/london-show-announced|title=London show announced!|work=Sophie Ellis-Bextor|access-date=22 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://sophieellisbextor.net/post/65683377534/tickets-for-sophies-london-union-chapel-show-on|title=Tickets for Sophie's London Union Chapel show on...|work=Sophie Ellis-Bextor|access-date=22 May 2016}}</ref> Ellis-Bextor then announced a 10-date UK tour, which finished in Glasgow in April 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.livenation.co.uk/artist/sophie-ellis-bextor-tickets?omq=sophie|title=Sophie Ellis-Bextor|work=Live Nation UK|access-date=22 May 2016}}</ref>

Ellis-Bextor collaborated with Guéna LG and Amir Afargan on the track "Back 2 Paradise", which was released in June 2014. The single was the number-one "breakout" in October 2014 on the [[Dance/Electronic Songs|US ''Billboard'' Dance/Club Chart]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/guenalg/posts/770348836357799 |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/iarchive/facebook/105353192857370/770348836357799 |archive-date=2022-02-26 |url-access=limited|title=Guéna LG|via=[[Facebook]]|access-date=22 May 2016}}{{cbignore}}{{Primary source inline|date=July 2022}}</ref> later reaching number 25 on the Dance/Club Chart.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.billboard.com/charts/dance-club-play-songs?page=2 |title=Billboard Dance/Club Songs Chart |magazine= [[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=2 January 2013 |access-date= 4 December 2014}}</ref> Ellis-Bextor then featured on the song "Only Child", produced by [[electronic music]] project DedRekoning, which was released in September 2014. The track was remixed by [[Paul Oakenfold]], Roddy Reynaert and Pearson and Hirst.

===2015–2019: ''Familia'' and ''The Song Diaries''===
[[File:Sophie Ellis-Bextor 2017.png|thumb|upright=0.8|Ellis-Bextor performing at [[White Party]] in Bangkok, Thailand in 2017]]
In January 2015, Ellis-Bextor said that she had begun working on her sixth studio album, once again with Ed Harcourt.<ref>{{cite tweet|user=SophieEB|author=Sophie Ellis-Bextor|number=560463114949656579|date=28 January 2015|title=We have begun! Day one songwriting for album 6 with edharcourt}}</ref> In January 2016, Ellis-Bextor posted an image on Instagram captioned "Last song written. Next stop – rehearsals! ''#album6 #whatthehellshouldicallit''." She also posted a YouTube video of the making of the album.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/music/news/a790494/sophie-ellis-bextor-is-back-with-new-album-familia/|title=Sophie Ellis-Bextor is BACK with new album Familia|website=[[Digital Spy]]|date=13 April 2016}}</ref>
According to Ellis-Bextor, the album, titled ''[[Familia (Sophie Ellis-Bextor album)|Familia]]'', was inspired by a recent visit to North America, particularly Mexico. ''Familia'' is the Spanish word for "family" (a tattoo Ellis-Bextor wears in her arm since her first child's birth) and Ellis-Bextor described the album's sound as closer to that of her earlier albums.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/SophieEllisBextor/videos/10154132467702628/|title=Sophie Ellis-Bextor|via=Facebook}}{{Primary source inline|date=July 2022}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ko17yNuSo5A| archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211107/ko17yNuSo5A| archive-date=7 November 2021 | url-status=live|title=The making of Familia (Album 6, coming soon...) |date=10 April 2016|via=[[YouTube]]|access-date=12 April 2016}}{{cbignore}}</ref> She explained that she "wanted something with a Spanish or Italian feel" and that it continued some stories from ''Wanderlust''. ''Familia'' was released in September 2016 and reached number 12 on the UK Albums Chart.<ref name="officialcharts"/> It spawned four singles, but none of them made it into any major chart. After taking time off for the birth of her child in late 2015, she resumed touring in 2017, mostly at small venues in the UK.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sophieellisbextor.net/shows|title=Shows|website=sophieellisbextor.net}}</ref>

In November 2017, she announced via Facebook a selection of her greatest hits reworked with an orchestra.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/BeqbhKElR2H/ |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/iarchive/s/instagram/BeqbhKElR2H |archive-date=26 December 2021 |url-access=registration|title=Sophie Eliis Bextor on Instagram on her Orchestral Greatest Hits|website=Instagram}}{{cbignore}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://sophieellisbextor.pmstores.co/|title=Sophie Ellis-Bextor: Orchestral Greatest Hits|website=PledgeMusic|language=en|access-date=19 May 2018}}</ref> In February 2018, she announced the album's title, ''[[The Song Diaries]]'', and pointed out that it would consist of re-recorded tracks spanning her career from [[theaudience]] to ''Familia'''s "Wild Forever", plus a new track. The album's artwork was drawn by David Downtown.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/SophieEllisBextor/posts/10155903585727628 |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/iarchive/facebook/6434097627/10155903585727628 |archive-date=2022-02-26 |url-access=limited|title=Orchestral Greatest Hits announcement|via=Facebook}}{{cbignore}}{{Primary source inline|date=July 2022}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/Bi7We8phOS9/  |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/iarchive/s/instagram/Bi7We8phOS9 |archive-date=26 December 2021 |url-access=registration|title=Sophie Ellis-Bextor's Instagram: Voila! The cover for The Song Diaries... |website=Instagram}}{{cbignore}}</ref> ''The Song Diaries'' first single "Love Is You", a disco track originally performed by [[Carol Williams (disco musician)|Carol Williams]], which is sampled on her early hit ''Groovejet'', was released in August 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sophieellisbextor.net/post/177030532892/qa-sophie-catches-up-about-the-album|title=Q&A: Sophie catches up about the album!|website=Sophie Ellis-Bextor|access-date=8 January 2019}}</ref> ''The Song Diaries'' was released in March 2019 and peaked at number 14 in the UK.<ref name="officialcharts"/>

=== 2020–present: ''Songs from the Kitchen Disco'' and upcoming album===

In 2020, during the [[COVID-19 pandemic in the United Kingdom|COVID-19 pandemic lockdown in the UK]], Ellis-Bextor performed live weekly "Kitchen Disco" concerts featuring herself and her family, streamed live from their kitchen on Instagram.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2020/apr/21/sophie-ellis-bextor-on-music-motherhood-and-lockdown-discos-most-of-my-children-are-feral|title=Sophie Ellis-Bextor on music, motherhood and lockdown discos: 'Most of my children are feral!'|first=Dylan B.|last=Jones|date=21 April 2020|work=The Guardian}}</ref> Starting 24 June 2020, Ellis-Bextor started a weekly podcast titled ''Spinning Plates with Sophie Ellis-Bextor'' in which she interviews working mothers.<ref>{{cite web |title=Spinning Plates with Sophie Ellis-Bextor |url=https://podcasts.apple.com/za/podcast/spinning-plates-with-sophie-ellis-bextor/id1521331095 |website=Apple Podcasts |access-date=18 September 2020}}</ref> Guests have included [[Fearne Cotton]], [[Caitlin Moran]], [[Myleene Klass]] [[Róisín Murphy|Róisin Murphy]] and [[Janet Ellis]].

On 16 July 2020, Ellis-Bextor announced the greatest hits album ''[[Songs from the Kitchen Disco]]''.<ref>{{cite web |title=Sophie Ellis-Bextor / Songs From The Kitchen Disco |url=https://www.superdeluxeedition.com/news/sophie-ellis-bextor-songs-from-the-kitchen-disco/ |website=Super Deluxe Edition |access-date=18 September 2020}}</ref> The album was preceded by the release of a single, "[[Crying at the Discoteque]]", a cover version of the [[Alcazar (group)|Alcazar]] song, which she had performed during her lockdown concerts in September 2020.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Ellis-Bextor|first=Sophie|date=18 September 2020|title=My new single, Crying At The Discotheque (from my upcoming Songs From The Kitchen Disco album)[...]|url=https://twitter.com/sophieeb/status/1306850386632990721|access-date=27 September 2020|via=Twitter|language=en}}{{Primary source inline|date=July 2022}}</ref> She performed the single on ''[[The Graham Norton Show]]'' on New Years Eve. In 2020, Ellis-Bextor competed in the [[The Masked Singer (British series 2)|second series]] of ''[[The Masked Singer (British TV series)|The Masked Singer]]'' as Alien. She was the first singer to be unmasked.<ref>{{cite web |title=First contestant revealed on The Masked Singer UK as Alien leaves |url=https://metro.co.uk/2020/12/26/the-masked-singer-uk-first-contestant-revealed-in-season-2-alien-13811515/ |website=Metro |access-date=26 December 2020 |language=en |date=26 December 2020}}</ref>

In March 2022, Ellis-Bextor embarked on her songs from the kitchen disco tour of the UK <ref>{{Cite web |last=Cummings |first=Bill |date=2022-01-19 |title=NEWS: Sophie Ellis-Bextor announces Kitchen Disco Tour |url=https://www.godisinthetvzine.co.uk/2022/01/19/news-sophie-ellis-bextor-announces-kitchen-disco-tour/ |access-date=2022-04-01 |website=God Is In The TV |language=en-US}}</ref>

In July 2022, the singer revealed a new single and uploaded its video. "Hypnotized" is a collaboration with electronic artist Wuh Oh and will feature in a forthcoming seventh album.

==Other projects==
In 2001 Ellis-Bextor auditioned for the 2001 film ''[[Moulin Rouge!]]'' for the character, Satine.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.contactmusic.com/new/xmlfeed.nsf/mndwebpages/bextor.s%20moulin%20rouge.%20misery |title=Sophie Ellis-Bextor – Bextor'S Moulin Rouge! Misery |publisher=Contactmusic.com |access-date=17 August 2010}}</ref>

In 2007 Ellis-Bextor appeared at Christmas in the ''[[Robbie the Reindeer]]'' episode, "Close Encounters of the Herd Kind". Ellis-Bextor was depicted as a female alien at the closure of the story, singing the song "Supersonic", the last track on her third solo studio album ''[[Trip the Light Fantastic (Sophie Ellis-Bextor album)|Trip the Light Fantastic]]''. In November of that year she also launched the [[npower (UK)|npower]] Greener Schools Programme, which aims to give schools in the UK a 'green makeover' by providing free energy audits, implementing tailor-made energy efficiency measures to reduce their carbon footprint, and educating children on how to be greener<ref>{{cite web |author=VIP Glamour |url=http://vipglamour.net/2007/11/16/sophie-ellis-bextor-greener-schools-programme |title=Sophie Ellis-Bextor Greener Schools Programme |publisher=Vipglamour.net |access-date=17 August 2010 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101227203940/http://vipglamour.net/2007/11/16/sophie-ellis-bextor-greener-schools-programme/ |archive-date=27 December 2010}}</ref> She also launched [[Capital Radio]]'s Capital 95.8 'Lights Out London' campaign, which asks Londoners to switch off their lights for one hour in a bid to save 750 MWh and send a message to the world on the importance of climate change.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://popdirt.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=61237 |title=Sophie Ellis-Bextor Launches 'Lights Out London' |publisher=popdirt.com |date=3 June 2007 |access-date=17 August 2010}}</ref>

In 2008 she featured in the short musical film ''The Town that Boars Me'' by photographer Ben Charles Edwards. The film also featureds Jodie Harsh, [[Kelly Osbourne]] and [[Zandra Rhodes]]. The film was produced by Glass Loves and Shoot to Kill Productions and was set to début at the Portobello Film Festival.<ref>{{cite web|author=portobello spy |url=http://www.portobellospy.com/2008/05/portobello-film-festival.html |title=Portobello Film Festival |publisher=Portobello Spy |date=31 May 2008 |access-date=17 August 2010 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091114033126/http://www.portobellospy.com/2008/05/portobello-film-festival.html |archive-date=14 November 2009 }}</ref> The same year she fronted a campaign for [[The Children's Society]] encouraging people to log onto the ''Hundreds and Thousands of Childhood Memories'' website to donate their favourite childhood memory.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/7213739.stm |title=Plea For Happy Childhood Memories |publisher=BBC News |date=29 January 2008 |access-date=17 August 2010}}</ref>

In May 2008 Ellis-Bextor was hired by cosmetics brand [[Rimmel]] as one of their new faces.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/celebritynews/2263801/Lily-Cole-and-Sophie-Ellis-Bextor-join-Kate-Moss-as-faces-of-Rimmel.html |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20220112/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/celebritynews/2263801/Lily-Cole-and-Sophie-Ellis-Bextor-join-Kate-Moss-as-faces-of-Rimmel.html |archive-date=12 January 2022 |url-access=subscription |url-status=live|title=Lily Cole and Sophie Ellis-Bextor join Kate Moss as faces of Rimmel|first=Anita|last=Singh|date=7 July 2008|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]}}{{cbignore}}</ref> A song by Ellis-Bextor, "Sophia Loren", was featured in one of the Rimmel London television adverts for the line "Sexy Curves".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://sophieellisbextor.net/post/45264597937/greetings-guys-and-girls-i-hope-you-are-all|title=Sophie Ellis-Bextor|website=Sophie Ellis-Bextor}}</ref> Ellis-Bextor appeared as an advocate for Verdi on [[BBC World News]] classical music programme ''Visionaries''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.visionariesdebate.com|title=デリヘル探しの極意～絶対後悔しない風俗～|website=visionariesdebate.com|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170709202437/http://visionariesdebate.com/|archive-date=9 July 2017}}</ref> In September 2014, the [[Pretty Polly (hosiery)|Pretty Polly]] hosiery company announced that she was their latest "face and legs", and would be designing and modelling for them.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eveningtimes.co.uk/entertainment/music/singer-sophie-ellis-bexter-is-the-new-face-and-legs-of-pretty-polly.1410265981|title=Singer Sophie Ellis-Bexter is the new face – and legs of Pretty Polly|work=Evening Times|access-date=22 May 2016}}</ref>

Ellis-Bextor was a contestant in [[Strictly Come Dancing (series 11)|the eleventh series]] of the televised dance competition ''[[Strictly Come Dancing]]'' in late 2013. She was partnered with [[Brendan Cole]] and reached the final, placing fourth.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.whatsontv.co.uk/news/sophie-ellis-bextor-finishes-fourth-in-strictly-final-119572/|title=Sophie Ellis-Bextor finishes fourth in Strictly final | Strictly Come Dancing|date=21 December 2013|website=What's on TV}}</ref>

In March 2019 Ellis-Bextor appeared as an extra in [[Game of Thrones (season 8)|''Game of Thrones'', Season 8, Episode 3]] "The Long Night".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.refinery29.com/en-us/2019/05/233788/who-is-sophie-ellis-bextor-game-of-thrones|title=After "The Last Watch," The One Remaining Question Is: Who Is Sophie Ellis-Bextor?|last=Milliner-Waddell|first=Jenna|website=refinery29.com|language=en|access-date=30 May 2019}}</ref>

In July 2020 she started a podcast called ''Spinning Plates'' which focuses on mothers and their careers.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Murray|first=Robin|date=6 July 2020|title=Sophie Ellis-Bextor Announces New Podcast Spinning Plates|url=https://www.clashmusic.com/news/sophie-ellis-bextor-announces-new-podcast-spinning-plates|access-date=27 September 2020|website=Clash Magazine|language=en}}</ref>

It was announced in October 2021 that Ellis-Bextor will make an appearance in the Australian soap opera ''[[Neighbours]]'' in 2022, as it airs a storyline in London.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.digitalspy.com/soaps/neighbours/a37895593/neighbours-spoilers-amanda-holden-london-harlow/|title=Neighbours casts Britain's Got Talent judge Amanda Holden for special London storyline|last=Lee|first=Jess|date=7 October 2021|work=[[Digital Spy]]|access-date=16 January 2022}}</ref> On the morning of 16 November 2021 Ellis-Bextor embarked on a 24-hour "Kitchen Disco Danceathon", in aid of [[Children in Need]].<ref name="auto">{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/entertainment-arts-59313641|title=Sophie Ellis-Bextor raises £800,000 in 24-hour Children In Need danceathon|work=BBC News|date=17 November 2021}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/events/egdwxj/live/c83g9r | title=Sophie Ellis-Bextor's Kitchen Disco Danceathon }}</ref> She raised over £1,000,000 for the cause.<ref name="auto"/><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://metro.co.uk/2021/11/17/sophie-ellis-bextor-raises-800k-for-children-in-need-with-danceathon-15615200/|title=Sophie Ellis-Bextor raises £800,000 for Children In Need with 24 hour danceathon|first=Emma|last=Kelly|date=17 November 2021}}</ref>

==Personal life==
Ellis-Bextor married [[the Feeling]] bassist [[Richard Jones (The Feeling)|Richard Jones]] in 2005.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hellomagazine.com/celebrities/2014090120725/sophie-ellis-bextor-talks-strictly-and-new-album/|title=Sophie Ellis-Bextor talks ''Strictly'', music and family life|date=1 September 2014|website=[[Hello!]]|access-date=12 August 2022}}</ref> Jones has said, "Something kind of smacked us in the face. The chemistry was incredible—it was like nothing I've ever experienced."<ref name="GuardianMarriage">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2013/sep/15/sophie-ellis-bextor-musical-marriage|title=Sophie Ellis-Bextor and Richard Jones on their musical marriage|first=Candice|last=Pires|date=15 September 2013|access-date=8 January 2019|work=[[The Guardian]]}}</ref> They have five sons.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hellomagazine.com/healthandbeauty/mother-and-baby/2019010766282/sophie-ellis-bextor-gives-birth-fifth-child-son/|title=Sophie Ellis-Bextor gives birth to fifth child – find out the gender and name|date=7 January 2019|website=[[Hello!]]|access-date=8 January 2019}}</ref> Their first child was born two months early, only eight months after the start of their relationship.<ref name="GuardianMarriage"/> Ellis-Bextor suffered from [[pre-eclampsia]] (the onset of high blood pressure) during her first two pregnancies, resulting in both deliveries being premature.<ref>{{cite news|last=Pointer|first=Anna|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/women/family/sophie-ellis-bextor-on-body-image-brexit---and-why-shes-not-ruli/ |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20220112/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/women/family/sophie-ellis-bextor-on-body-image-brexit---and-why-shes-not-ruli/ |archive-date=12 January 2022 |url-access=subscription |url-status=live| title=Sophie Ellis-Bextor on body image, Brexit — and why she's not ruling out baby number five| work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]| date=12 September 2016| access-date=30 May 2017}}{{cbignore}}</ref> She is an ambassador for Borne, a medical research charity looking into the causes of premature birth.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.borne.org.uk/about/patrons-ambassadors/|title=Our Patrons and Ambassadors|website=Borne|language=en-GB|access-date=22 May 2019}}</ref>

==Political activity==

In the [[2019 European Parliament election in the United Kingdom|2019 EU Elections]] Ellis-Bextor endorsed [[Change UK|The Independent Group for Change]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/sophieeb/status/1125668409117745152|title=My dad @RobinBextor is the candidate for @TheIndGroup in the south east. He's always been passionate about politics so it's lovely to see. I agree with his politics, but whether you're leave or remain it would be good to put an end to the current nonsense with a people's vote.pic.twitter.com/K0LRyG0QH1|first=Sophie|last=Ellis-Bextor|date=7 May 2019|access-date=7 April 2020}}{{Primary source inline|date=July 2022}}</ref> Her father, [[Robin Bextor]], was a candidate for the [[South East England (European Parliament constituency)|South East Region]]. He obtained 105,832 votes but lost his deposit, as he did not obtain at least 5% of the vote.
